wind up.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to bring an activity, meeting etc to an end
wind up.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: OK, just to wind up, could I summarize what we’ve decided?

wind up.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to close down a company or organization

wind up.translation[0].definitions[2].de: to be in an unpleasant situation or place after a lot has happened
wind up.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: You know you’re going to wind up in court over this.
I wound up wishing I’d never come.
wind up.translation[0].definitions[3].de: to deliberately say or do something that will annoy or worry someone, as a joke
wind up.translation[0].definitions[4].de: to turn part of a machine around several times, in order to make it move or start working
wind up.translation[0].definitions[5].de: to make something, especially a car window, move up by turning a handle or pressing a button
wind up.translation[0].definitions[5].ex: Could you wind the window up, please?
wind up.translation[1].definitions[0].de: something that you say or do in order to make someone angry or worried, as a joke
wind up.translation[1].definitions[1].de: a series of actions that are intended to complete a process, meeting etc
wind up.translation[1].definitions[1].ex: The president made a statement at the windup of the summit in Helsinki.
wind up.translation[2].definitions[0].de: relating to a machine or toy that you turn part of several times, in order to make it move or start working
wind up.translation[3].definitions[0].de: to close down a company, especially because it cannot pay its debts

wind up.translation[3].definitions[1].ex: Mr Reid wound up the meeting with a summary of the main resolutions.
